title: Voices Shouting In The Rain
description:
Video here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EaHpkGtqG80

What was before the Big Bang? Well... the question itself doesn't really make sense - the concept of "before" implies motion in the time dimension. This dimension didn't exist until the big bang so the idea of there being something "before" it is meaningless.
That said, there is a notion of oscillating universes - from big bang to big crunch and then another big bang, over and over... who knows how many universes there were before this one. But then again, what's the difference really. It's all about your frame of reference. Stuff here on Earth is what's important, whether or not it really exists.
This is a rough cut using stock footage just because I didn't want to pay hundreds of pounds to Shutterstock, who I appear to be advertising here instead. But you get the idea anyway: SPAAAAAAAAAAAAAAACE :)

title: Magic Of Our Time
description:
Full EP available here: https://michaelforrest.bandcamp.com/album/magic-of-our-time-ep 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Sm4rJjVxNFQ 
This is the title track of my new EP "Magic Of Our Time".
When I wrote this song I was thinking about the nature of technology and progress. It is easy to take the wonders of the modern world for granted, or quibble about the details, losing sight of the fact we are safer and more connected to each other than any other humans in history.

title: Talk Or Die - preview track from Magic Of Our Time EP
description:
Full EP available here: michaelforrest.bandcamp.com/album/magic-of-our-time-ep

This is the first track from a the forthcoming EP "Magic Of Our Time". It has a cheerful, experimental tone and the chorus vocals become more digital as the song progresses, as if retreating into a computer instead of following through on the sentiment... 

 The lyrics are inspired by Philip K Dick's essay "Schizophrenia and the Book of Changes" - "The preschizophrenic personality is generally called "schizoid affective", which means that as an adolescent he still hopes that he won't have to ask the cute chick (or boy) in the next row for a date. Speaking in terms of my own schizoid-affective experience, one gazes at her for a year or so, mentally detailing all possible outcomes; the good ones go under the rubric "daydreams," the bad ones under "phobia." This bipolar internal war goes on endlessly; meanwhile the actual girl has no idea you're alive (and guess why: You're not)." -- Philip K Dick

The lyrics in full: "If I could I'd offer you a cigarette / but something better's needed or you're gonna leave me disappointed and full of regret / You've got such a unique way about you / I would go to pieces if you stood up / Before I met you even if I screwed up / I know why this place and time is where I say hi, say hi, say hi / If I resist, I cease to exist / It's talk or die, it's talk or die / We could make a perfect pair / Of fascinated, syncopated, complicated specimens / It only takes a second to say yes yes yes yes yes yes yes yes / And we're never looking back / And I know why this place and time is where I say hi, say hi, say / If I resist, I cease to exist / It's talk or die, it's talk or die"



Updates on this release will be through Facebook: http://facebook.com/michael.forrest.music

title: Infinite Music Machine Sixty Minute Mix #1
description:
This mix is a sort of arbitrary cross-section through the possibilities of the Infinite Music Machine's output. I recorded 1000 different loops at the same tempo and in the same key and then use software to play those loops in different combinations and algorithmically generated sequences.

The sounds themselves come from a range of sources: from home-made synths, toy keyboards, digital drums, real drums, a Moog guitar, pianos, electric pianos, a real life harmonium, strange little sound-making objects, several different iPhone and iPad apps, a Teenage Engineering OP-1, various software synthesisers and a kazoo.

title: Super Singular (This Girl)
description:
This track was originally about a machine ("This machine has confidence / it's super singular") but I changed it to be about a girl instead. Sell out? ;)

Also shared as https://soundcloud.com/9pr/michael-forrest-super

title: Infinite London - available now on Bandcamp
description:
Here's Infinite London, the first taste of the sounds from the Infinite Music Machine, an app-based 'album' coming to the App Store in March. 

Here's the video: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HIgq-FPlugE

Go to Bandcamp for the single to purchase, including a bonus track / b-side "Super Singular".

"A hive, a warren of creativity, London remains a perpetual source of inspiration to those who live there.
After all, it's so dense, so sprawling, that it can often seem like London is - for all intents and purposes - the world itself.
Michael Forrest calls the city his home, using it as an interface to consume music. The artist's own productions fuse these influences into one unholy beast, matching the lurid IDM of, say Amon Tobin, with the glitch-hop of early Flying Lotus.
Throwing in slabs of indie's more cerebral side, Michael Forrest is set to release new single 'Infinite London' on February 10th.
A swarm of noise and texture, the video for the track rushes around London in a technicolor race to the finish." - Clash Music http://www.clashmusic.com/videos/premiere-michael-forrest-infinite-london

"Pleasingly intense and hypnotic stuff" - Guardian Music Blog http://guardianmusic.tumblr.com/post/75910906413/michael-forrests-infinite-london-in-march-uk

"Multi-instrumental production wizard Michael Forrest makes glitchy, atmospheric electronica that prods and pokes your brain in a very agreeable way." - TimeOut http://www.timeout.com/london/music/squares-michael-forrest-justin-paton

"Michael Forrest's 'Infinite London' swivels dangerously to and fro. Bionic jab after bionic jab, there are instances of melodiousness attempting to surface; sweet pastel shades pushed down by heavy metallic torrents which deliver a brisk suaveness that is quintessentially London.
The ambiance of the bustling city perfectly captured within the cool dynamic of the song, the outro is suddenly maniacal -- a reflection of the unsettling, luminous solitude of city life, but also the fortitude and addiction to drive that come with it. Indeed, Forrest is thoroughly self-aware. He brands his music as unmarketable pop, but its blatant defiance of the commercial is perhaps what propels him above the rest, producing a sound that is attention-grabbing, artistic and strong.
Michael Forrest: a name ready to bask in the warm glow of many a cold, industry-run city: New York, London, Paris, Tokyo...
That is, if the rest of his forthcoming record Infinite Music Machine is on par with the single. Primal, yet robotic; a straight-shooter with a tight structure."
Rock'n'Roll In My Soul - http://rnrinmysoul.com/review-infinite-london-by-michael-forrest/

"he's a London based producer who classes his music as unmarketable pop - but I do have a lot of love for his brand of skitchy, jerky, dark electro-pop. 'Infinite London' is an unpredictable, nightmarish ghoul of a tune that lurches in to life before infiltrating your veins and blood cells via your ears. Elements of Cho Cho, Prodigy and Goose are apparent but there is a throbbing, pulsating bass melody that has something quite delicious about it. This is the kind of music that should be found reverberating along the walls of some multi-roomed, neon painted pop up nightclub that is only accessible via a large cat flap with a ninja on security duty. It's off the wall, it's odd, it's got a groove and I love it." - Listen With Monger http://listenwithmonger.blogspot.co.uk/2014/01/michael-forrest-single-review.html

"With elements of both rave and techno-pop, it has quite a unique feel to it. It has some catchy grooves partway through, with a pulsating bass melody throughout. It's unpredictable, random and could be considered somewhat eerie at times, but it's definitely something that you'd expect to hear in a nightclub where everybody is covered in UV paint and partying all night long" - Hold Up Now http://holdupnow.com/michael-forrest-infinite-london/

"'Infinite London', the first fun and infectious cut lifted from the album, serves as an excellent taste of what's coming our way." - Cast The Dice http://castthedice.org/?p=7028

"strangely alluring experimental electronica" - MiddleBoopMag

Also shared as 
https://soundcloud.com/9pr/michael-forrest-infinite
https://soundcloud.com/9pr/michael-forrest-infinite-1

tag_list: op-1 vocals du m r reason
title: #13. When You Gonna Do It
description:
MF Tuesdays #13. New track every week.

I had to take a day out of work to get this one done. The tone was influenced by this fact.

Full disclosure: I may have listened to Actionist Respoke by Mouse On Mars once or twice before.

title: #11. Bathtime For Robot
description:
MF Tuesdays #11 - new track every week

I spent Sunday working very hard trying to perfect a vocal style hybrid of Lou Reed, Jeffrey Lewis, David Bowie, Sean Ryder and Mark E Smith. I wasn't happy with the result as it stood by Monday so I dug this electronic number out and managed somehow to draw it out beyond my minimum 3:00 duration for an MF Tuesdays track.

I'm feeling good about my improvements in terms of subtlety. This has turned out pretty great considering three hours ago I didn't feel like I had anything to share this week!

The lead synth, pictured, is Bebot - an iPhone / iPad app that you can get from the App Store. I like it a lot.

title: #10. All my tech still works in desert
description:
MF Tuesdays #10.

I have spent the week in a Morocco, in a guesthouse on the edge of the Sahara; it's about as remote as you can get without requiring specialised modes of transport (e.g. 4x4s or snow scooters). 

In some ways this recording is exactly what you'd expect to hear under these circumstances  - noodly quartertones etc... I like it though. It's a one-take live recording made with my iphone featuring my OP-1 and the Animoog iPad synth. 

Let's say it's about how technology comes with you one way or another, wherever you go. 

Typo carried through to artwork to retain desert authenticity (I didn't notice because I had to type it in on my iPhone). Artwork inverted because Matt said it looked like Hotel California as a straight picture which is not an association I want.

title: Booted
description:
MF Tuesdays #9

This is relatively acoustic compared to my usual output.

I got this snare drum and wanted to hear it on something. 

It's a little loose in places but what do you expect when it's me playing piano, drums, trumpet, glockenspiel, synth, arranging and mastering the whole thing within, like, two days... Also, the artwork doesn't make itself! ;)



I'm flying to Morocco today for a holiday.

title: Languishing
description:
MF Tuesdays #8

I recorded this one with Reason - first time I've used it since it got audio recording features. I also bought a couple of cymbals, a shaker and a snare drum to add to this track. This meant I had to also get a filing cabinet and assemble that before disassembling my desk and packing that away to make space for the drums. I think it was just about worth it though. 

Also it was my birthday yesterday and I was at Field Day / Apple Cart over the weekend so didn't have a lot of time this week! Hence no vox. And the Tortoise influence.

This is also MF Tuesdays #6

tag_list: synth massive crazy smoke electribe op-1 vocals
title: #4. Going Crazy
description:
MF Tuesdays #4

I listened to Radio 1 this week to see what the kids are listening to these days. Then I made this. Being crazy seems to be a staple of pop music so I'm comfortable with that. 

This is the closest I think I can get to big pop without a vocal coach and a producer who will discourage me from throwing in creepy stuff about spiders (dubbed out for this 'radio edit').

Enjoy, share. Thanks.

title: Bonus piano track (I wanna see you tonight)
description: One of the offcuts of my new song that I'll put out tomorrow.

tag_list: piano sink instrumental happy dubstep op-1 trumpet
title: #3. And Me With No Umbrella
description:
MF Tuesdays #3 - New track every Tuesday
Katherine wanted me to combine the piano tune she'd woken up with (most audible here from 1:59) with a dubsteppy loop I had on my OP-1. I had the little piano / clarinet / trumpet bit already (it was called 'speak when ya spoken to'). Finally, my kitchen sink is prone to making dubstep noises so these can be found, bringing a rainy day watery vibe to the whole thing.

tag_list: electronica song pop horror vocals piano dark electribe op-1
title: #2. Make You Mine
description:
MF Tuesdays #2 - New MF track every week

I keep seeing these Ryan Gosling films recently where he perseveres with a lady until she finally gives in and then subsequently falls in love. 

However, whenever I send even so much as a second text message to someone who seems reluctant to get to know me I start to feel like I'm being a crazy stalker psychopath. So here's a feel good horror song from the perspective of a crazy stalker psychopath.

Think of it as being in the tradition of Nick Cave and his murder ballads. Or like some kind of dubstep Dexter.

Should I have done it all in the first person? I'm not sure... I hope the Daily Mail don't call the police on me.  

The artwork is a painting by Marcus Alexander - mdjalexander on Twitter.

The intro is courtesy of Natalie's brain.

This track will always remind me of the time I didn't take the opportunity to talk to David Shrigley in real life.

tag_list: electronica song optimistic trumpet vocals electribe
title: #1. Nothing Bad Can Happen
description:
MF Tuesdays #1

This is the first in a series of potentially indefinite length, where I will be uploading a new track every Tuesday.

This month I decided to become a 'glass half full' person. I suspect this will have a strange and marked impact on the music I create. Because this is certainly the most positive thing I've ever produced.

Name-your-price download available here: 
http://michaelforrest.bandcamp.com/track/nothing-bad-can-happen
